choices.text: The incubation period varies from 9 to 90 days
Serum from the chancre is infectious

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding primary syphilis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The chancre in primary syphilis is painless and indurated.

Induration is a key clinical feature that helps distinguish it from other genital ulcers, like chancroid, which are painful and soft.

Syphilis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the spirochete Treponema pallidum, the only treponeme responsible for venereal disease. It is often referred to as the "great imitator" due to its wide range of clinical manifestations.

Note:

Special sign in primary syphilis - Dory flop sign:

  • When a chancre of primary syphilis is located on the undersurface of the prepuce, the affected skin becomes indurated and inelastic. Upon retraction, the prepuce does not roll back smoothly, but flips abruptly all at once — mimicking the motion of a "dory", a flat-bottomed fishing boat that flips suddenly when overturned.
  • It is suggestive (not diagnostic) of syphilis and aids in early diagnosis

choices.text: Symmetrical vesicular lesions on the trunk
Snail track ulcers on the oral mucosa

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with lesions over the perianal area (as shown in the image). He also complains of low-grade fever, malaise, and arthralgia. On examination, generalized lymphadenopathy is present. Which of the following is NOT a recognized feature associated with the underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows condyloma lata, a hallmark cutaneous manifestation of secondary syphilis, which is characterized by flat-topped, moist papules in the anogenital region.

  • Secondary syphilis typically presents 2-8 weeks after the primary chancre, with systemic symptoms (fever, malaise, arthralgia), lymphadenopathy and mucocutaneous involvement.
  • Rash in secondary syphilis is non-vesicular (macular, papular, or papulosquamous), often involving palms and soles; vesiculobullous lesions are not seen.

choices.text: Benzathine penicillin G, 2.4 million units IM, single dose
Aqueous crystalline penicillin G IV for 10-14 days
Doxycycline 100 mg twice daily for 14 days
Penicillin desensitization followed by penicillin therapy

questions.text: A 28-year-old non-pregnant woman presents with painless genital ulcer and generalized lymphadenopathy. Serological testing confirms a diagnosis of early syphilis. She reports a history of penicillin allergy. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
This is a case of early syphilis in a non-pregnant woman with penicillin allergy. In such cases, the recommended alternative is doxycycline 100 mg twice daily for 14 days.

Management of Syphilis:

  • DOC for Non-neurosyphilis cases: Inj. Benzathine Penicillin G
    • Dose: 2.4 million units, Deep IM after AST (1.2 million units on each buttock)
    • Early syphilis (primary, secondary, early latent): 1 dose
    • Late syphilis (late latent, tertiary, duration unknown cases): 3 doses (once weekly)
    • Note: Benzathine Penicillin G does not cross blood-brain barrier
  • DOC for Neurosyphilis: Inj. Aqueous Crystalline Penicillin G
    • Dose: 18-24 million units/day, IV route
    • Duration: Daily for 10-14 days (requires hospitalization)
  • DOC, if allergic to penicillin (Non-pregnant cases): Doxycycline 100 mg BD
    • Early syphilis (primary, secondary, early latent): For 14 days
    • Late syphilis (late latent, tertiary, duration unknown cases): For 28 days
  • 2nd DOC in penicillin allergy: Macrolides
  • DOC, if allergic to penicillin (Pregnant cases):
    • Penicillin desensitization → Followed by Penicillin therapy
    • Desensitization (Mechanism): Repeated low-dose penicillin → Binds to IgE on mast cells/basophils without cross-linking → prevents degranulation → tolerant to higher doses.

Explanation of Other Options:

Benzathine penicillin G, 2.4 million units IM, single dose (Option A): First-line for early syphilis, but contraindicated in penicillin-allergic patients.

Aqueous crystalline penicillin G IV for 10-14 days (Option B): Used for neurosyphilis, not indicated in early syphilis without CNS involvement.

Penicillin desensitization followed by penicillin therapy (Option D): Effective but not preferred in non-pregnant patients; reserved for pregnancy or when alternatives like doxycycline are contraindicated.

Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 10th Edition, Page Numbers: 29.20 - 29.21

questions.text: A patient being treated for secondary syphilis receives a single dose of benzathine penicillin G (2.4 million units IM). The next day, he presents with an acute onset of fever, myalgia, arthralgia, and worsening of skin lesions. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient’s symptoms are characteristic of a Jarisch–Herxheimer reaction (JHR), an acute febrile inflammatory response occurring within 24 hours of antibiotic initiation for spirochetal infections like syphilis. It is not an allergy, but a cytokine-mediated inflammatory response to the rapid lysis of spirochetes.

Explanation of Other Options:

Treatment failure (Option A):

  • Treatment failure is not immediate.
  • It is evaluated based on persistent symptoms or failure of serological response over weeks to months. Acute febrile symptoms one day after treatment are more indicative of JHR.

Penicillin allergy (Option B):

  • Allergy to penicillin typically presents with immediate hypersensitivity features such as rash, urticaria, angioedema, bronchospasm, or anaphylaxis, rather than fever and rash exacerbation.
  • Also, IgE-mediated allergy occurs in minutes to hours, not typically the next day.

Hoigné syndrome (Option D):

  • This is a rare neuropsychiatric reaction following IM injection of procaine penicillin, not benzathine penicillin.
  • Presents with anxiety, hallucinations, dizziness, tachycardia and does not involve fever or rash exacerbation.

Reference:

Jarisch-Herxheimer Reaction - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents for a routine check-up. He reports no current symptoms but recalls having a painless genital ulcer approximately 6 months ago that resolved spontaneously without treatment. He denies any rashes, mucosal lesions, or systemic symptoms. Physical examination is unremarkable. Serological tests for syphilis (both treponemal and non-treponemal) are positive. What is the most likely stage of syphilis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient had a genital ulcer 6 months ago (likely a chancre of primary syphilis) and now has no clinical signs but positive serology. This fits the criteria for early latent syphilis, defined as asymptomatic infection within 1 year (CDC) or 2 years (WHO) of initial infection.

Explanation of Other Options:

Secondary syphilis (Option A): Typically occurs 2 to 8 weeks after the primary chancre heals and presents with systemic symptoms (fever, malaise) and mucocutaneous manifestations such as rash, mucous patches, and condyloma lata. This patient lacks such features.

Late latent syphilis (Option C): Defined as latent syphilis occurring more than 1 year (CDC) or 2 years (WHO) after infection. Since this patient’s infection is recent (6 months), this diagnosis is incorrect.

Tertiary syphilis (Option D): Occurs years after an untreated infection and presents with gummatous lesions, cardiovascular syphilis, or neurosyphilis. These are not seen in this patient.

Reference: 

Jarisch-Herxheimer Reaction - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf.

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely to be seen in tertiary syphilis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Tertiary syphilis occurs years after the initial infection and represents a non-contagious phase marked by chronic, slowly progressive tissue damage. It typically manifests as gummatous lesions, cardiovascular involvement, or neurosyphilis.

Gummas are non-infectious granulomatous lesions caused by a delayed hypersensitivity immune response, not by active spirochetemia.

Reference:

Jarisch-Herxheimer Reaction - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf.

questions.text: A patient presents with a solitary, painless ulcer at the same anatomical site as a previously healed syphilitic chancre. The lesion is non-tender, non-infectious, and not associated with regional lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given scenario is suggestive of pseudochancre redux, a solitary gumma reappearing at the site of a previously healed chancre, typically in tertiary syphilis. It is non-infectious, painless, and not associated with regional lymphadenopathy.

Relapsing Syphilis ("Redux")

  • Redux means "to return."
  • It refers to the reappearance of lesions at the site of a previously healed chancre.

Explanation of Other Options:

Erythroplasia of Queyrat (Option A): A premalignant, HPV-related squamous cell carcinoma in situ of the glans penis or prepuce. Presents as a well-demarcated, moist, red, velvety plaque with a high risk of progression to invasive malignancy. It is unrelated to syphilis.

Bowen's disease (Option D): A premalignant, HPV-associated squamous cell carcinoma in situ of keratinized penile skin (e.g., shaft). Appears as a solitary, scaly, erythematous or crusted plaque with moderate malignant potential. Not linked to syphilitic infection.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant born to a mother with untreated syphilis presents with persistent nasal discharge and swelling of the right upper arm. Examination reveals hepatosplenomegaly. X-ray of the long bones is shown below. Which of the following is most likely seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The infant shows signs of early congenital syphilis, including snuffles, hepatosplenomegaly, and periostitis (evident on X-ray as Wimberger’s sign). These lead to Pseudoparalysis of Parrot, where the infant avoids moving the limb.

Mulberry molars, Hutchinson teeth, and interstitial keratitis are features of late congenital syphilis. (Options A, B and C ruled out)

Congenital Syphilis:

Congenital syphilis (CS) results from transplacental transmission of T. pallidum from an infected mother to fetus during pregnancy (or rarely during delivery via active genital lesions).

Untreated maternal syphilis can lead to fetal loss, still birth, prematurity, and infant complications (deafness, neuro deficits, bone deformities), but is preventable with timely penicillin and good antenatal care.

Diday-Kassowitz Law: In untreated syphilitic mothers, the risk of transmission decreases with each successive pregnancy. 

Classification:

Early Congenital Syphilis: Appears <2 years of age; infectious.

Late Congenital Syphilis: Appears >2 years of age; non-infectious (immune-mediated damage).

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in late congenital syphilis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Late congenital syphilis is characterized by features like saber shins (anterior bowing of tibia - Option A ruled out), mulberry molars (enamel hypoplasia of molars - Option B ruled out), and palatal perforation (d/t gummatous destruction - Option D ruled out).

Erythema multiforme (Option C) is an acute hypersensitivity reaction typically triggered by infections (like HSV) or drugs and is not associated with congenital syphilis. Its hallmark is the presence of target lesions, which differentiates it from syphilitic findings.

choices.text: Benzathine penicillin G 2.4 million units IM single dose

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with painful genital ulcers that developed 5 days after unprotected sexual contact with a commercial sex worker. On examination, the ulcers are tender, non-indurated, have ragged, undermined edges, and bleed on touch. He also has unilateral, tender inguinal lymphadenopathy. A Gram stain from the ulcer exudate is shown below. What is the most appropriate treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient has classic features of chancroid:

  • Painful, non-indurated genital ulcer with undermined edges and bleeding on touch (soft chancre)
  • Unilateral tender inguinal lymphadenopathy (bubo)
  • Recent high-risk sexual exposure
  • Gram stain shows gram-negative coccobacilli in a “school of fish” pattern, which is diagnostic of Haemophilus ducreyi.

Azithromycin 1 g orally (single dose) is a first-line treatment for chancroid

Explanation of Other Options:

Benzathine penicillin G 2.4 million units IM single dose (Option A):

  • Used for syphilis, not chancroid
  • Syphilitic chancre (aka hard chancre) is typically painless, indurated, with clean base and heals spontaneously
  • Inguinal nodes are rubbery, bilateral, and non-tender

Metronidazole 2 g orally single dose (Option C):

  • Used for anaerobic and protozoal infections like trichomoniasis, BV, and amoebiasis
  • Not effective against Gram-negative bacteria like H. ducreyi

Doxycycline 100 mg BID for 7 days (Option D):

  • Used for Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV)
  • LGV presents with a small painless ulcer, often unnoticed, followed by painful bilateral lymphadenopathy (buboes), which may become fluctuant
  • Can also be used in treating Chlamydia

Explanation:

Trachomatis isolates exist as 15 serovariants.

Trachoma - ocular tropic strains (A, B, Ba, and C)

Genitourinary tract tropic (D, E, F, G, H, I, J, and K) strains Invasive lymphogranuloma venereum (L1, L2, and L3)

The causative agent of LGV is Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1-L3.

choices.text: Intracytoplasmic chlamydial bodies in epithelial cells and leukocytes
Multinucleated giant cells and intranuclear inclusions

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presents with a painless genital ulcer as shown in the image. Which of the following is most likely present in the tissue smear sample of the ulcer?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient's presentation of painless genital ulcer, beefy red appearance, and absence of lymphadenopathy is characteristic of granuloma inguinale (Donovanosis), which is caused by Klebsiella granulomatis, a gram-negative intracellular bacterium.

Diagnosis is made by crush tissue smear stained with Giemsa, revealing:

  • Donovan bodies: Intracytoplasmic coccobacilli within large mononuclear macrophages (Pund cells)
  • These organisms show bipolar chromatin condensation, appearing like “closed safety pins”

Explanation of Other Options:

Intracytoplasmic chlamydial bodies in epithelial cells and leukocytes (Option A):

  • Seen in lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) caused by Chlamydia trachomatis (L1–L3 serovars).
  • Features include transient painless ulcer followed by tender lymphadenopathy (buboes).

Multinucleated giant cells and intranuclear inclusions (Option B):

  • Characteristic of genital herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection.
  • The ulcer is usually painful, and Tzanck smear shows multinucleated giant cells with Cowdry type A intranuclear inclusions.


Organisms in parallel strands (Option D):

  • Seen in chancroid, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.
  • The ulcer is painful with undermined edges, and smears may show school-of-fish or railroad-track arrangement of bacilli.

Key Takeaway:

  • Klebsiella granulomatis causes donovanosis
  • Leishmania donovani causes leishmaniasis

choices.text: Presents with painful ulcers and non-tender lymphadenopathy
Tzanck smear shows multinucleated giant cells
Genital herpes is managed syndromically using the Red Kit

questions.text: Which of the following statements about genital herpes is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Genital herpes presents with painful ulcers and are typically associated with B/L tender lymphadenopathy.

Genital Herpes:

  • Etiology: 
    • Caused by Herpes Simplex Virus: HSV-2 (M/c, ~90%) > HSV-1 (~10%)
    • Incubation period: 3–12 days (option D ruled out)
  • After primary infection → virus remains latent in sacral ganglion → causes recurrent episodes
  • Clinical Features
    • Primary lesion: Multiple grouped vesicles (<1 cm) on a red base. Vesicles rupture → erosions with polycyclic margins
    • Ulcer stage: Painful, shallow grouped ulcers
    • Lymph nodes: B/L, tender, enlarged inguinal lymphadenopathy
  • Investigations
    • Tzanck smear shows:
      • Multinucleated giant cells (with intranuclear eosinophilic Cowdry A inclusions) (option B ruled out)
      • Herpes also causes secondary Acantholysis → Acantholytic cells ("Tzanck cells") with large round nuclei and perinuclear halo
  • Treatment:
    • Acyclovir 400 mg TID × 7 days for primary infection (STI syndromic management: Red kit) (option C ruled out)
    • Acyclovir 400 mg TID × 5 days for recurrences

questions.text: A 38-year-old man who has sex with men (MSM) presents with chronic genital swelling as shown in the image. He reports a painless genital ulcer a few months ago that resolved spontaneously, followed by tender inguinal lymphadenopathy, which later ruptured. What is the most likely underlying etiology?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical picture and history are classic for Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV)—a sexually transmitted infection caused by Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1–L3. It typically presents with a painless genital ulcer, followed weeks later by painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (bubo) that may rupture. 

Chronic lymphatic obstruction can lead to genital elephantiasis, seen here as saxophone penis.4

Explanation of Other Options:

Donovanosis (Option B):

  • Caused by Klebsiella granulomatis
  • Painless, beefy-red ulcers that bleed easily
  • Lymphadenopathy and lymphatic obstruction are not features, so genital elephantiasis is not typically seen

Secondary syphilis (Option C):

  • Caused by Treponema pallidum
  • Presents with mucocutaneous rash, condyloma lata, and generalized, non-tender lymphadenopathy 
  • It lacks bubo formation or chronic genital swelling, which are characteristic of LGV

Filariasis (Option D): 

  • Caused by Wuchereria bancrofti, leads to chronic lymphatic obstruction and genital elephantiasis, but not preceded by genital ulcer or buboes
  • It is a systemic parasitic disease, not sexually transmitted
